fields.name: Field of Study
fields.description: Disciplinary or clinical field, such as primary care, oncology, or public health
fields.evidence_quote: "Keywords: pediatric urinary incontinence, nocturnal enuresis, behavioral therapy, urotherapy, patient compliance, digital health, serious games, telehealth, health technology, enuresis alarm, artificial intelligence, AI"

fields.name: Country
fields.description: Country or countries where the study was conducted or primarily situated
fields.evidence_quote: <sup>1</sup>Department of Research and Development, Minze Health NV, Antwerp, Belgium

fields.name: Type of Article
fields.description: Classify the article: original research, protocol, review, commentary, etc.
fields.evidence_quote: "Innovative, Technology-Driven, Digital Tools for Managing Pediatric Urinary Incontinence: Scoping Review"

fields.name: Aim of Study
fields.description: State the main purpose or objective of the study as described by the authors
fields.value: To identify and map innovative, technology-driven, digital tools for managing pediatric urinary incontinence.
fields.evidence_quote: "This scoping review aimed to identify and map innovative, technology-driven, digital tools for managing pediatric urinary incontinence."

fields.name: Key Findings
fields.description: Summarize the main results or conclusions of the study
fields.value: Six main categories of digital tools were identified: digital self-management, serious games, reminder technology, educational media, telehealth and remote patient monitoring, and enuresis alarm innovations.
fields.evidence_quote: "Our analysis led to the identification of six main categories of tools: (1) digital self-management (7/66, 11%); (2) serious games (7/66, 11%); (3) reminder technology (6/66, 9%); (4) educational media (12/66, 18%); (5) telehealth and remote patient monitoring (13/66, 20%); and (6) enuresis alarm innovations (21/66, 32%)."

fields.name: Patient/Public Engagement (Y/N)
fields.description: Does the study report any meaningful or intentional involvement of patients or the public in any phase of the research or implementation?
fields.evidence_quote: Patient engagement in medical device design: refining the essential attributes of a wearable, pre-void, ultrasound alarm for nocturnal enuresis.

fields.name: Type of Engagement (Montreal Model continuum)
fields.description: Categorize engagement based on the Montreal Model: Information (e.g., newsletters), Consultation (e.g., surveys, focus groups), Collaboration (e.g., co-design sessions), or Partnership (e.g., decision-making roles, advisory boards).
fields.evidence_quote: Patient engagement in medical device design: refining the essential attributes of a wearable, pre-void, ultrasound alarm for nocturnal enuresis.

fields.name: Level of Patient Involvement (Montreal Model)
fields.description: At what level were patients or the public involved across the research lifecycle? Score each phase (design, development, evaluation, implementation) as: None, Information, Consultation, Collaboration, or Partnership.
fields.value: Design: Consultation, Development: None, Evaluation: None, Implementation: None
fields.evidence_quote: Patient engagement in medical device design: refining the essential attributes of a wearable, pre-void, ultrasound alarm for nocturnal enuresis.

fields.evidence_quote: Patient engagement in medical device design: refining the essential attributes of a wearable, pre-void, ultrasound alarm for nocturnal enuresis.

fields.evidence_quote: Patient engagement in medical device design: refining the essential attributes of a wearable, pre-void, ultrasound alarm for nocturnal enuresis.

fields.name: Persuasive Design Techniques
fields.description: Were behavior-change strategies or persuasive technologies mentioned (e.g., nudges, gamification, reminders)?
fields.value: Yes - Rewards such as in-application trophies and stars.
fields.evidence_quote: These self-management applications incorporated features such as weekly modules with exercises; daily goals; self-monitoring of parameters such as fluid intake, toilet visits, medication, and mood status; reminders; progress tracking; personalized feedback; and rewards such as in-application trophies and stars.

fields.name: Assess Impact
fields.description: Did the study measure outcomes or success metrics related specifically to engagement efforts?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Information
fields.description: Was information provided to patients/public about the study, without involving them in decision-making?
fields.value: Yes - Educational media for delivering health-related information to patients
fields.evidence_quote: (4) Educational media for delivering health-related information to patients, which was subdivided into videos and other types of educational media.

fields.name: Consultation
fields.description: Was patient or public input sought (e.g., through interviews, surveys, focus groups), without involving them in decision-making?
fields.value: Yes - Patient engagement in medical device design
fields.evidence_quote: Patient engagement in medical device design: refining the essential attributes of a wearable, pre-void, ultrasound alarm for nocturnal enuresis.

fields.name: Collaboration
fields.description: Was there shared decision-making or co-design between researchers and participants in any phase of the study?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Partnership
fields.description: Were patients/public involved across all stages with formal roles (e.g., co-authors, advisory board, project governance)?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Equity or Inclusivity Considerations
fields.description: Did the study aim to include marginalized or underrepresented groups in the engagement process?
fields.value: Yes - Equitable access is another challenge for health care innovation, especially in low-resource settings.
fields.evidence_quote: Ensuring equitable access is another challenge for health care innovation, especially in low-resource settings.

fields.name: Ethical, Legal, and Social Implications (ELSI)
fields.description: Did the study address privacy, informed consent, data ethics, or cultural relevance in its engagement or implementation approach?
fields.value: Yes - Ensuring patient privacy and data security remains a critical challenge for digital health care innovation.
fields.evidence_quote: Ensuring patient privacy and data security remains a critical challenge for digital health care innovation.

fields.name: Technology Complexity / Integration Readiness
fields.description: Did the study evaluate how complex the technology was or how well it integrated with existing clinical or community workflows?
fields.value: Yes - Integrating RPM systems such as the UTI monitoring system may mitigate these technical barriers by providing valuable data for remote support and enhancing patient and parent self-efficacy.
fields.evidence_quote: Integrating RPM systems such as the UTI monitoring system may mitigate these technical barriers by providing valuable data for remote support and enhancing patient and parent self-efficacy.

fields.name: Real-World Evaluation or Deployment
fields.description: Was the technology evaluated or deployed in real-world settings beyond pilot studies or lab prototypes?
fields.value: Yes - Home uroflowmetry biofeedback showing promise and patient preference
fields.evidence_quote: Both uroflowmetry and EMG biofeedback were described as effective in reducing symptoms in patients with DV, with home uroflowmetry biofeedback showing promise and patient preference.

fields.name: Feedback and Iterative Adaptation
fields.description: Was feedback from participants used in an ongoing way to adapt the design, strategy, or evaluation?
fields.value: Yes - Feedback from children using the urotherapy serious game indicated a desire for more dynamic gameplay that adapts to their training progress.
fields.evidence_quote: For instance, feedback from children using the urotherapy serious game indicated a desire for more dynamic gameplay that adapts to their training progress.
